text: just over ten years ago an evolutionary
psychologist designed a study
investigating people's Christmas card
lists the tradition of sending a
Christmas card is in itself an
interesting behavior yet it gives us
clues about one of the things that
defines us as human through our
evolution the social brain the social
brain hypothesis suggests that human
intelligence evolved to negotiate our
complicated social group we have these
complex behaviors and the more
information that we need to store and
manipulate about our environment the
bigger the computer needs to be what's
really interesting is that one part of
our brain the neocortex is correlated
with the size of our social groups the
neocortex is their outer layer about
brain and it's responsible for our hyper
functions like conscious thought
language or spatial reasoning
researchers looked at the neocortex of
other primates and compared it as a
ratio to the size of the rest of their
brain and they found a pattern
Leamas with the smaller neocortex Ligon
social groups of nine long nosed monkeys
with a larger neocortex living groups of
14 the western red colobus monkey
slightly larger neocortex again lives in
groups of 35 and the chimpanzee with the
largest neocortex of all primates except
for humans lives in a social group of 53
so hypothetically we could apply this
pattern to humans but because we don't
all live in local groups and because we
don't groom each other it's kind of
tricky to work out our social network
sizes so this is where the Christmas
cards come in in the Christmas card
study participants were ours how many
people that were sending cards to how
far away they were the last time they've
been in touch and how emotionally close
they were researchers found the average
number of cards sent was 68 and because
you can send a card to more than one
person the average social network size
was 153 people but the study is kind of
problematic
you can send cards for political as well
as social reasons and people put a
different amount of thought into their
Christmas card list if you celebrate
Christmas or send cards at all the
psychologist who designed the Christmas
card study was Robin Dunbar one of not
very many people who has a number named
after them the Dunbar number is the
limit of meaningful relationships that
one person can maintain that the number
doesn't have a precise value in the
early 90s using that primate neocortex
ratio and applying it to humans dumbo
estimated his number to be a hundred and
fifteen meaningful relationships per
person it's consistent with group size
in Neolithic farming villages and armies
in Roman antiquity and because our
neocortex can only be so big it's
actually hard for our brain to
accommodate more relationships been
thinking about the size of a Neolithic
farming villages literally comparing the
present to the Stone Age what does the
Dunbar number mean now and is it
changing with our ever expanding social
networks even though you might have 300
friends on Facebook or a thousand
followers on Instagram you only have so
much time
friendships are maintained by investing
time in them sure a status update or
posting a photo is efficient you don't
spend as much time but it's not as
personal as a form of communication
Dunbar suggests we need face-to-face
interaction to maintain quality
relationships physical proximity to our
friends and loved ones means we release
more endorphins and have a
higher level of oxytocin which we need
for social bonding sure our neocortex
ecity to grow and develop to suit our
environments it's possible that kids of
today will have a different neural
organization to handle the changes in
our social interactions studying today's
children is some ways away by which time
traditions such as this one could be a
relic from the Stone Age
